One thing I learned in my theory of computing class is a non-deterministic machine vs a deterministic one. The algorithm of a non-deterministic machine (like a quantum computer) can compute things much faster than a deterministic machine (like a classical computer) but the trade of is getting the right answer. In a non-deterministic machine, the possibility of getting the right answer is not 100% like the classical computer. Although it will compute one cycle through the machine it might get the desired result or might not.
So if the goal is to get the right answer, you might have to run the machine many times until you get it.
For example if you would like to see if the string 0011 is accepted in a non-deterministic machine, because it's a 4 bit string there are 16 possible combinations so you might have to run the machine 15 times until you reach the desired 0011 but there is also the possibility to reach it on the first try, in which case it would be faster than a classical computer.
This is why it isn't "faster" than a classical computer but better for specific situations. In fact, like he said in the video, the operations are probably slower exponentially because of the amount of possible combinations for the output.

(I'm not a master, I only just learned this and am writing a paper report on quantum computers, so please correct me if I'm wrong)

Regular computers: yes no

Quantum computers: P E R H A P S

C-bit, P-bit and Q-bit - Classical bits are special case of Probabilistic bits where the probability of being in state 1 is either 100% (1) or 0% (0). Q-bits are Probabilistic bits with not just amplitude (positive square-root of its probability of being in state 1) but also phase making it best represented as a complex number. Another representation is like an angle T, where amplitude is sin T, so sin^2 T is the probability of being measured as state = 1 and cos^2 T is the probability of being measured as state = 0.

So what I am getting from it is that  just like there are different states of Matter there are different states of Quantum computing.  A classical computer uses classical operations which can be 0 OR 1 while Quantum computing can use 0 AND 1 at the same time.  Physical objects like a Nucleus or electron can work as physical objects used as a Qubit.

Ok I think this is a good way to explain it: You know how you flip a coin over and over again and eventually you get the solution that 50% of your flips are heads and 50% are tails? That is how classical computers work, they take into account only the end state of the flip (landing on heads/tails). In contrast, the quantum computer uses the transitional period in between end states (the coin flipping in the air) to reach the solution of 50/50 much faster than the traditional method. This means that with a quantum computer you may only have to flip the coin 20 times (for example) instead of 150 times with the traditional computer.

I think it's not correct to say that a quantum computer has 2^n classical bit, because it has a number for each possible qubit state, so it's 2^n numbers (or actually 2^n - 1 numbers, because the sum of the squares has to be one, so e.g. for 2 qubits a²+b²+c²+d²=1  =>d=sqrt(a²+b²+c²), so the 4th number depends on the other 3, so it doesn't contain information, but this doesn't make much difference for real quantum, computers which have high numbers of qubits). But each of this number needs more than 1 bit because it can not only be 0 or 1. In theory every number is precise, so you would in theory need infinite classical bits to store every number, in reality of course it depends on how accurate you can measure the probabilities.

We are not digital and nothing in Nature is digital. Digital computers are an exact science with exact results. Nature is based on "good enough is good enough". Oxford quantum physics professor Andrew Steane wrote in his paper about quantum information systems titled "Quantum computing" at https://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/9708022.pdf :

"The new version of the Church-Turing thesis (now called the ‘Church-Turing Principle’) does not refer to Turing machines. This is important because there are fundamental differences between the very nature of the Turing machine and the principles of quantum mechanics. One is described in terms of operations on classical bits, the other in terms of evolution of quantum states. Hence there is the possibility that the universal Turing machine, and hence all classical computers, might not be able to simulate some of the behavior to be found in Nature. Conversely, it may be physically possible (i.e. not ruled out by the laws of Nature) to realize a new type of computation essentially different from that of classical computer science. This is the central aim of quantum computing."

From what I understand they are forcing current quantum computers to unnaturally apply a binary state to something that has a infinite evolution of states. Think of the electron and the circle it makes around a nucleus. That 360 degrees circle it makes is infinite in precision, and that movement certainly has an effect on its surroundings. Basically, practical math is the descriptive language of the universe, and not the actual universe because it uses measurements.

I propose a "Dynamic Stateless Computer" that operates on "Logic Geometry" based only on connections, or links, or pointers - a much more simple computer than the three basic Boolean logic gates operating on mathematical binary bits that is every computer out there. The shape is the logic and the logic is the shape, sort of like a truth table that is dynamic where the "truths" change as it runs.

Quantum mechanics is beyond me, but if this only needs connections, ie a quantum entanglement, can we build a computer that operates and does its entire run instantly? Like I said, all I need is connections to perform logic... no need for information... the shape is the logic.

You are best off going to Github and seeing online without downloading the paper and models. When someone looked at my calculators, they accused me of: "You're not doing math! You're emulating math!" Look at the simple calculator first, it only does addition and subtraction. Then look at the complex calculator that does multiplication and division. As you well know, if I can do those things, I can do anything mathematically. In the main model I created if-thens, complex do-whiles, a randomizer and a relational database.

Through the exercise of the most complex do-while I asked a question related to that, and the answer uses the ancient Chinese/Pascal's Triangle (which millions have looked at over thousands of years) in a new way: https://mathhelpforum.com/threads/combination-lock.17147/ I basically had to count nothing as something to count, as in you can have different items to count the permutations of but a default state of no item is possible for each, some or all to count in the permutations, and it doesn't seem anyone else in history was able to use the really basic mathematical concept of the Triangle in that way for the solution. It is similar to the 4 hats and 4 pegs question of how many permutations you can have that is commonly associated with Pascal's Triangle, but they did not count the empty pegs as part of the permutations that they can have. The technique of the implementation is a little interesting, with it being able to reach any of the 209 possible permutations of 4 wheels with 4 numbers (don't know if I should count 0, it is special in this case - if you do count 0, it is 5 numbers) in 4 keystrokes or less - it's how it scales that is the curiosity, where if I had 18 slots and 18 items to form a permutation it would have almost 3x10 to 18th power or 2,968,971,264,021,448,999 possible permutations, each reachable within 18 keystrokes or less.

We are not digital. Nothing in nature is digital. Oxford quantum physicist Andrew Steane wrote that 'Turing machines may not be able to simulate some of the behavior in nature', basically because digital computers can't deal with infinity. I have a new type of logic that doesn't use measurements, only connections, or links, or pointers.

I have come up with what I believe is a new type of logic, it is mechanical in nature, but because I think I could see it done on the quantum level it could be far more complex than any mechanical machine has ever been, in ways not seen in physical mechanical devices.

I call these examples a "dynamic stateless computer" based on "logic geometry". The logic is pure connectionism, only using connections (or links/pointers), and nothing else. My working models perform the logic only using one command without alphanumeric variables, without logic operators, and without the need for measurements. This is neither digital nor analog logic.

This is not theory, In my working models using this logic they demonstrate if-thens, do-whiles, a randomizer, a relational database and other logic, including a rudimentary calculator that adds/subtracts/multiplies/divides - which I was accused of, "You're not doing math! You're emulating math!" In the working model I only use one command for hooking in the input (a link or pointer or connection), a few commands for output, but all the logic in between is one command (alias) that does nothing but link a string of commands into one new command or overwriting an old command.

Note that this is logic that could work without using Boolean logic gates on binary bits like every traditional Turing machine device that you have uses.

The paper is a work in progress, I need help with this as I have zero experience writing papers:

That's such a backwards way of explaining quantum computers...  We should first start with stating the problems we are trying to solve and why the classical computers fail. Trying to solve the Shrodinger's equation for an atom more complicated than a hydrogen atom - you have to track interaction between so many quarks and electrons that the time complexity of the algorithm solving the equation grows as O(n!) where n is the number of quantum particles in the system. 20! is already such a big number that it takes months for the equation to be solved, and 100! is simply impossible - even if you set all of the computers available at the beginning of the time they will fail to compute the position and the energy of a quantum system consisting of 100 quantum particles. So here enters quantum computer or a quantum simulator where you have these particles available to you directly so you can manipulate them, put them in certain state, then let them interact and then directly measure their state instead of simulating it with a classical computer. How do you go from tinkering with Q-bits to simulating real world quantum systems - enter quantum algorithms which essentially make the translation to and from Q-bits interaction to real world quantum system interaction. So that ladies and gentlemen is the quantum computer and the very reason it exists.

I think i get it..

A classical computer is faster for single computations. It does one thing at a time very quickly. And as every bit it has available increases, it can do another single computation per bit available - this is a linear increase.

For quantum computing, it can do a single computation per bit available. However, when you add available bits, it can run in parrallel an exponential number of computations.

The difference is noted when the computing power is used for finding results of a function with a changing variable. A classical computer must run each equation one bit (or 2) per t time, and if there are n bits, it will run at 2n bits per t time. Whereas with a quantum computer, it can run a function at one bit (or 2) per t time, and with n bits, 2^n bits per time.

So for say trying to find the encryption password for any secure network, quantum computing will find it exponentially faster than classical computing.

Actually, this isn't hard to understand, but it is hard to get your head around. Quantum states  exist in probabilities. However, to be observed, they must be in a fixed state. When not being observed, they are "probably" in one state or the other. The act of observation fixes the state of the particle, according to its probability of being in that state. Look up, "quantum gates" to see an explanation based on unitary matrices for an idea of how the math works.

What this would result to is, that data which requires GBs of memory, in a quantum computer, would require only few MBs.

I might be wrong, but here it is in simple terms:

Bits are 1s or 0s. A certain order of such bits make different commands, letters, numbers, etc. So for example, an “A” might be 1110011101 (not actually). Computers take time to go through all these numbers, and they take up space.

Quantum computers have different bits, bits that can be more than just 1s and 0s. This means that “A” could just be 34 (again, not actually), so there is more room for info and computers can go thru them easier.

Then you can explain how a multiplication works.
People can immediately get an idea how such a computer might work.

To put this simply the process of ‘quantum’ computing is a method of detecting the dielectric potential of the object being observed at a very specific time. For example instead of having bits of either 0 or 1 this process divides this into a scale. The scale may be out of 100 in which the number 40 is closer to 0 or an off bit.

When two objects are close together they share their dielectric potential which increases the difficulty in determining where on the scale both of the objects would be.

And of course when the two objects share their dielectric potential, as with all matter in the universe, there is great uncertainty of exactly where the dielectric is spread out amongst its combined self.

What is clear is that coherent energy, or matter, is a self contained stable magnet. What is happening in the process of ‘quantum’ computing is the changing of the coherent matters magnetic stability by adding energy.

Adding energy changes the dielectric potential which is shared by all other ‘quantum’ bits.

So now the quantum bits share a slightly elevated energy state. But because of the natural stable magnetic properties of each ‘quantum’ bit there is an interplay of expanding magnetic fields which shifts the dielectric, or added energy, to someplace else. In this instance to a region of lesser dielectric.

A direct comparison are waves on the ocean. There are waves coming from all over going this way and that, up and down, to the left or right and all exchanging a little bit of their energy to everything around it. It never stops moving and this is what the dielectric is doing.

When a measurement is made to determine the state of the bit, the very act of measuring requires a removal of a small amount of dielectric. Therefore that measurement acts as a reset to the quantum bits to their natural resting state.

So when you go out and look at the ocean try to think how easy it would be to go measure a wave in amongst all the other waves, when all the other waves are moving and changing that wave you want to measure.


Quantum is just another word for the study of the properties of coherent matter.

Once that connection is realized the process of advancing our understanding of the universe will take a giant leap forward.

In other words,
A Quantum Computer
Effectively Operates As If
It IS USING Base 3, instead of Base 2
That means for an address or calculation
There can be 3 values -
"0 or 1 or 0&1"
or
Values of 0, 1, or 2

While the computer you're using and I'm using
Uses Base 2 and
Can only have for an address or calculation
2 values -
"0 or 1"

That difference means it takes far less space to store information
and
Far fewer calculations to calculate a value.

So quantum computers aren't fast due to their individual operations being faster, but due to the fact that they require far fewer operations.  Very insightful. Imagine a classical program that outputs you the quickest route to get from your house to the store. It must analyze every possible path there in order to compare and determine which path is shortest. It does this incredibly quick, however it requires enormous amounts of operations to give you the answer. A quantum computer, on the other hand, can process every possible path simultaneously, therefore requiring far fewer operations in the first place.

So basically
2 bits - 2 storage units, each of them contains either 0 or 1
2 qubits - 2 storage units where each contains 00, 11, 1 and 0 or 0 and 1.
0's and 1's are representing the state of the storage unit. While for bits it's impossible to have state different from 0 or 1, for qubits in the 2-spin system there are 4 possible combinations, so they can store twice as much information (2qubits*2information each)

If you don't get it, imagine it like this:
The classic computer runs everything in smaller volume at a really fast rate.
While the quantum computer runs everything exponentially larger, but not necessarily faster.

Let's say, a calculation of 2*8:
Classic computers take 1 second to finish the calculation in one single step of 1 second per step
Quantum computers take 5 seconds to finish the calculation in one single step of 5 seconds per step
2*8-5:
Classic computers take 2 seconds to finish the calculation in two steps of 1 second per step
Quantum computers take 5 seconds to finish the calculation in one single step of 5 seconds per step
2*8-5/4^9+2331*812:
Classic computers take 6 seconds to finish the calculation in 6 steps of 1 second per step
Quantum computers take 5 seconds to finish the calculation in one single step of 5 seconds per step

Where each so called bit can represent a value between 0 and 1 (corresponding to a qubit representing a probability between 0 and 1). This is used in signal compression in communications. And of course this is just a compressed signal; the signal can be uncompressed into packets of amplitudes that get represented digitally.

Or is is more comparable to a fuzzy computer, where all of the math is done between 0 and 1, but in the end we only care about 0 or 1?

Quantum computers use qubits, which create physical Superpositions in their own state-of-point positions. Quantum computers share theoretical similarities with non-deterministic and probabilistic computers, but do not have similarities with a digital computer. Both practical and theoretical research continues, and many national governments and military agencies are funding and supporting quantum computing research in effort to develop quantum computers for business, trade, and national security purposes, such as cryptanalysis. Large scale quantum computers will be able to solve certain problems much more quickly than any classical computers that use even the best-in-use algorithms, like integer factorization using Shor's algorithm or the simulation of quantum main-body systems. There exist Quantum Algorithms, such as Simon's Algorithm, that run faster than any probabilistic classical algorithm.
Any 14-dimensional vectors that a Quantum Algorithmic Computer can use, can calculate it into the same operational matrix vector. A Quantum computer can terminate an algorithm at a lightning-fast rates, which then calculate the algorithm and convert it into trillions of quantum codes, and break it down into smaller basic blocks each light second that passes by. Light Seconds aren't a real or formal unit rate, but I'm trying to make a point.

Funny thing about quantum computers. As their function is inherently dependent on probability, they are essentially probabilistic determining machines. "Given these inputs and this process, we're about thiiiss certain the outcome will be..." So, they're apparently faster at solving certain equations, but those equations must be run numerous times to verify their validity. That's counterproductive.

Also, I don't understand the usefulness of 2^n bits of manipulable information if the output will only ever be n bits of information. It's useless for storage. I suppose you could structure the algorithm that manipulates the qubits in such a way that the outcomes are coded to meaningful values, but then you limit 2^n possibilities to just n possibilities. That's like taking 10 cars apart just to build one new one (though really closer to 64 to 6).

Also, I have yet to see any explanation of how the information is manipulated. In a classical computer, 0 + 0 = 0, 0 + 1 = 1 (and vice verse), and 1 + 1 = 0 with a left carry. How does it work in a quantum computer? I get that coefficients of probable outcomes can be manipulated and tested via measurement, I get that qubits can be flipped between states and set in a superposition or entangled (potentially representing mutual exclusivity of outcomes?) or destructively/constructively interfere, but I don't get how that all comes together, or why people haven't moved on to explaining that stuff yet. That would really get the wheels rolling on the whole quantum computer bandwagon.

Also, then, I don't understand why this video is called "How A Quantum Computer Works," when it says nothing of quantum computation, only how superposition works, and that a quantum computer utilizes an electron of an independent atom as a qubit. It doesn't even cover entanglement and wave-function collapse.

Congratulation. You just explained randomized computation.
 
If the power of quantum computer had come from superposition of all 2^n numbers then randomized computation would have given us the same power.  Because even in randomized computation we have probability distributionn over all possible numbers. And similar to what you explained, the outcome of the experiment is always just one number with certain probability distribution.

It is just that in quantum computation, the amplitudes can be a "complex number" (instead of real numbers) and thus unlike randomized computation amplitudes can actually cancel out.  So probably this is where the power comes from. But in reality nobody yet knows why.



And if you look from complexity point of view, set of all problems that are solvable by quantum machine in polynomial time is called BQP. Now we know that BQP contains P. P is the set of all problems that can be solved by classical computers in polynomial time.  So certainly whatever can be done by a classical computer in polynomial time can indeed be done by a quantum computer in polynomial time.

Now factoring can be done in polynomial time by a quantum computer (Thanks to Peter Shor). We don't yet know a polynomial time classical algorithm for that. So quantum is powerful in that sense.
But don't get too excited as there is a interesting class of difficult problems called NP-complete. Actually most interesting hard problems seat there. And we don't yet know if NP is in BQP.

Excellent video that explains a little bit of the basic idea of quantum computing and how it can be physically implemented. Summary: Electrons can be manipulated and aligned like magnetic particles to store information. n Quantum Bits = 2^n Classical Bits, which means that a mere 300 quantum bits is impressively equal to (approximately) the number of particles in the universe. However, this situation turns out to be an advantage only for LARGE computations. Therefore, quantum computing is mainly a SUPPLEMENT to classical computing, not a replacement.

Basically most computers work by
1. creating a state in which maths can be done (creation)
2. inputing via units (bytes) (input)
3. do the calculations (calculation)
4. Measure the output of the calculation and output the measurement (output) (measure) (display)

When you are done, the state reverts to step 1, meaning you can either output your maths back into it to do another calculation or you can display the output. There is no "reset" because it never left the ability to calculate.

For the quantum computer
1. start with a state in which you can create a state where math can be done
2. Create a state in the particles in which math my be done, the state you put them in is your input (creation) (bytes) (input)
3. measure the state, thus precipitating the calculation and output the measurement (calculation) (measure) (output) (display)

The computer has to be reset afterwards because the base state its self becomes the output wherein the base state of a normal computer stays the same and just facilitates the maths.

It's like a normal computer is 500 dominos that you calculate which ones would fall based on the input of a domino in the middle. A quantum computer is placing 2^300 dominos in uncertain possitions, leaving the room, and when you enter the room you see where all 2^300 fell at or did not fall at. The normal did not change base state but output the calculation. The quantum changed base state to calculate a large single program


tl:dr quantum computers are more efficient if you need to run a single GIANT program. Normal computer operations are based off of several millions of operations to do any amount of calculation/display.

We'll probably get a little quantum computing device at some point as part of our classical electronic (by then nanoelectronic, of course) CPUs, with a special "QCE" ("Quantum Computing Extensions") or so instruction set extension.

Like we had x87-coprocessors (or, respectively, starting with the 80486DX, on chip FPUs).

The type of operations which are right for quantum computing are a very limited class: it's when you need to find out a very limited set of result values (like 1 number, for example, or, at most, a few of them) from a very large set of calculations.

The 2^300 example is very good in this regard - you can easily get 4 relatively high precision fixed point values (I don't think that quantum computers will internally work with IEEE floats, because they are far too complicated to handle, but fixed point mathematics is easy to implement) in 300 bits.

Yes, this would be great... a "QPU", like we also have (now legacy) "FPUs".

I've watched a few science videos now in which the explanations in the end were always quantum, quantum, quantum, and it was starting to annoy me a little, so I clicked this one to see if I could finally have some clarity on this subject. Honestly, I couldn't. I can't bring myself to accepting the concept of "two states at the same time".

1:35: "When you measure the spin, it will be either up or down"

So, end of the story, isn't it? It's up or it's down, period. It shouldn't "allow the electron to exist in both states before you measure it". If I secretly put a book inside a box and give the box to you, telling you that it may contain either a book or a phone, it won't change the fact that I already put a book in it. A phone will not materialize itself inside of the box, existing together with the book just because I told you there could be a phone in there. Your doubt won't change what I already did, since my actions are not subject to your observation or to "what you think". If "when you observe it, you will see only one of the two states", then it is not "something existing at two states at the same time" but rather "not knowing in which of the two possible states something exists". To be able to proclaim that "it exists in two states at the same time", you would have to "observe it existing in two states at the same time". Now that I think about it, doesn't the whole definition of "state" revolves around being in a condition that is different from other conditions you could be in? I mean, what would be the point of the concept of states even existing if it weren't like that? Can you be both "hungry" and "not hungry"? Can "A" and "not A"? This breaks even logic. It's paradoxical.

2:54: "To determine the state of this two-spin system, I need to give you four numbers, four coefficients, whereas in the classical example of the two bits, I only need to give you two bits. So this is how you understand why 2 qubits actually contain 4 bits of  information"

Doesn't this make the qubit just the same as a pair of bits then? Where's the benefit? Moreover, if those coefficients represent the probability of the state in question being one or the other (1:43), isn't a qubit actually worse at transmitting information than a pair of bits? After all, if you have to deal with probabilities to determine a state, that's prediction, which is subject to failure, while a pair of bits is always accurate and therefore more reliable (and would also be faster, since you wouldn't need extra calculations to make any predictions in the first place).

All this makes me think that, either I still don't quite grasp what quantum physics is all about or there is some serious mistake with the terminology being generally used to describe its principles (or maybe both). That's one thing about science that bugs me: when people use affirmations as bold as "two states at the same time" when that's not what is actually happening.

One example - 21 can be differentiated in two prime numbers, 3 and 7. (3x7=21) Lets say you do it the hard way, then you had to calculate with all prime numbers smaller than 21 like this... 2x2=4, 2x2x2=8, 2x2x2x2=16, 2x3=6... you get the point.

To compute the prime factorization of a 300 digit number, the fastest computers on earth would need roughly 150 years. A QC could calculate ALL interim states with ALL possible combination of prime numbers AT ONCE. And thats the voodoo.

What is explained in the vid IS the voodoo. The point is that IF you can extract the information stored in the superposition you have a computer able to do CERTAIN things real fast, but ONLY those things. Like the Shinkansen is FAST, but only on rails. QCs would be really fast when computing things you can find out by trial-and-error, like cracking passwords or prime factorization, since it would be able to compute all interim states at once.

So if what i understood is right, then quantum computers are bad for executing simple linear programming and better suited for execution of parallel computing of multiple possibilities all at once. But wouldn't it be so that we are still in our infancy on the knowledge, possibilities & practicalities of QC and is yet to figure out efficient programming logic to make the most out of this new realm?

Quantum effects seem to be sent faster than light. (the EPR paradox. An example involves the quantum states of 2 particles that are entangled. But, it's impossible to control which state the 1st particle will have, so info can't be sent in this manner.

You wouldn't be able to examine a "record" of the individual computations, since that information is lost when the output is measured. No, you can't use Bytes here, because one Byte consists of 8 Bits and if you talk about one Byte, those 8 Bits are not separated.

If you take 8 separated bits, you can store 2 conditions for each bit, resulting in 16 different conditions. Only if you entangle those 8 bits, you get 256 possible conditions.
This is exactly the same like 8 entangled quibits or 8 entangled SETUN-Threebits.

8 bit = 2^8 = 256 conditions
8 quibits = 4^8 = 65536
8 SETUN-Threebits = 3^8 = 6561 conditions

I think you're thinking on parallel computing: you have a lot of values, perform a lot of operations on those values, and get a lot of results (which you can later sum or print or save or whatever).
In quantum computing, something similar happens, except that at the end you get ONLY ONE of the results, so it's not exactly the same as parallel computing (if I understood correctly).
In the QC approach, you consider all the possible results, discard the wrong ones, and keep the right one.

It's not about how many states there are: for example, bytes have 256 possible states (which is a lot more than 3) and are no different than having 8 separate bits.  The thing is that 8 "entangled" qubits would store WAY more information than the 8 qubits separately.
According to this video, 10 qubits could hold about 1 KB of data, but twice as many qubits wouldn't hold 2 KB but about 1 MB.

I can measure the spin of one, and then know that the other one is the opposite. But I can't transmit the spin signal (up or down) that I want. Thus no communication can be established.
An analogy: Say you had a tall pencil that covered 2 floors; you are observing one end on the first floor and your friend is observing the other on the second floor. The pencil points up or down. If you walk in and see the bottom of the pencil, then you that your friend must be seeing the top of the pencil.

Np, I'm always happy to talk about physics. One common misconception is that entanglement allows you to transmit information instantly. Special relativity says that this is impossible, it causes some rather bizarre paradoxes. The important thing to note about 2 entangled electrons is that you can't control the spin of either electron, you can only measure it. Classical reversible logic gates are gates that input as many classical bits as they output. There are combinations of such logic gates that are Turing Complete (can compute anything other logic gates can). A circuit made of these gates is called a reversible circuit.

A reversible quantum circuit is made of reversible quantum logic gates. Except that these gates take in an N bit entangled quantum state and output another. Such circuits are the basis of quantum computing.

2 electrons cannot be in the same state. So if 2 electrons are bound to, say, a helium atom, they must have different spins (one up, one down) because they share all other Quantum Numbers.

In this state one wave function describes both electrons. So if one electron has spin up then the other MUST have spin down due to the principle above (Pauli exclusion principle). Separating them doesn't change this. But once the wave function is measured, the system decoheres and entanglement is lost.

Because ultimately you can only transmit data at the speed of light-in-vacuum so even with perfect interconnects you still have that limit. Also, there is a thing called the Bekenstein bound that limits how much computation is even physically possible in a given space containing a given energy. So yes, even the most advanced imaginable technology (say, a neutron star brain) would ultimately run into limitations. Needless to say though, we're nowhere close to that kind of limit.

...you'd need something that can switch states faster than the voltages in a transistor and something that can convey signals between switches faster than the metal interconnects in modern chips. Photonics and spin-based classical devices both have potential to switch faster, and photonic interconnects can potentially transmit more data faster than electronics. Ideally you'd want your switches to be extremely tiny and for them to be as close together even in more advanced technologies.

It's incredibly hard to project out to 2100, but we can project from now to say 2030 with mild accuracy. Dennard Scaling, the thing that was allowing classical 'cores' to go faster and faster, slowed down hard in the early 2000s when transistors went below 100nm, leading to a switch to parallelism and multiple cores. Modern transistors aren't much faster than they were in 2005, but they are smaller, hence more things can be done in parallel. For increases in serial processing power...

No you are not understanding. 1 quantum bit does not store 4 possible values. In superposition 1 qbit stores 2 simultaneous non-binary values and when observed stores 1 binary value based on spin up or down. When 2 qbits in superposition are entangled they store 4 simultaneous non-binary values. Hence 2^N "numbers" as he refers to them. Then collapsing back to binary when observed. A classical bit can have more than one possible value, 0 or 1, but it only represents one of those values at a given time. I used the term scalar because as presented two entangled quantum bits in superposition do not represent 4 possible binary values but rather 4 possible probabilities.

QC is about exploiting certain quantum-mechanical effects to execute computations on rather small datasets (a few hundred bits at most), but which need a lot of classical computational steps (typical example: breaking an encryption key, which is typically 128 or 256 bits). Problems with few computational steps but high data volumes aren't good for that (e.g. HD video playback).
As for transistor replacement: we'll simply have to design a new "switch" type circuit that uses different physics.

The "both 0 and 1" is a bit of a misnomer we use to teach to the general public. It is not a classical system, it is not halfway in between or any other amount in between. It is not 0 nor 1, nor both. But it is in a completely different quantum state in which it is undecided which it is until you measure it. This quantum state is often a complex experssion which defines a wave of probability which defines the probability of it collapsing to either 0 or 1 when you make a measurement.

A quick note about parallel, 
Usual parallel processing means you can send different tasks all over the place and through some very complex working bring it all together.
In contrast a Quantum processor does the same task but covers vast chunks of that one task simultaneously. E.g. if there are 100 possible answers to a given problem a quantum computer will deal with every one of them at the same time ending with the most probable answer.

Hopefully that helps clarify what tasks it is good for.

What the prof. means is that no matter how you rewrote the code, you still wouldn't get a significant benefit from using a quantum computer for many operations.  Because you can only read out n classical bits of information from n qubits, if the processing required isn't huge compared to n, classical parallelism would do just as well.  The largest benefit would most likely be for problems that take exponential time classically, for example 2^n operations. :)

- Queries. (meaning, not a program, but a question with an algorithm)

- that is slow for classical computers. (Usually this means exponential-time calculations, such as the traveling salesman problem, which has a 'perfect' answer but takes exponential time to get to it)

And you must have (w,x,y,z) a 1-norm vector.

Only if every one of those functions (ray tracing, the specific rendering calculations of every separate element) are included in the set of calculations that can be performed with a quantum computer.

Those sorts of tasks are better suited to classical parallelism, because although in concept, one could write down a quantum algorithm to try to make use of quantum computers for rendering, 1) it has to beat the classical rendering algorithms that are already easy to parallelize, and 2) if you have n qubits, you can't read out more than n classical bits of information from a measurement.  You need tasks where the processing to solve it is very significant compared to the output size. :)

A quantum computer based on known physics is not able to solve undecidable problems in finite time, because a classical computer can simulate a quantum one with a polynomial factor extra space and an exponential factor extra time.  However, it may (or may not) be that the set of problems that a quantum computer can solve in polynomial time is larger than the set of problems that a classical computer can solve in polynomial time.  Hopefully that clarifies things for you. :)

The point is to use your uncertainty of which position they are in. There are four possible combinations and you only describe the probability of the two (seen as a whole) being in either one of the four combinations. If you know the probability for a, that doesn't give you the probability for the last three - but if you knew the first three, you'd be able to deduce the last. In a three spin system, you'd need the first seven to know the last.

You need 4 when dealing with a binary system: 00, 01, 10, 11.  The first example was only with one bit of information: either a 1 or a 0.  If they were dealing with 3 bits, 8 coefficients would be necessary for accounting for each state: 000, 001, 010, 011, 100, 101, 110, 111.

Observation is used to refer to contact with another quantum system. Since observation as we know it requires contact with other quantum systems, we use what Latins called 'pars pro toto', if memory serves.

The advantage of QuantComp on ClasComp does not stem from the different number of parameters needed to specify a state. If your classical state is a mixture of the possible states of 10 cbits you would need 2^10 coefficients (less one or two following normalization and other constraints). For various algorithms, the power of quant-comp comes from entanglement or rather from the fact that these coefficients - amplitudes are complex.

lets say you have 2 (q)bits. so there are 4 cassical states: 11,01,10,00
in quantum mechanics you have the same 4 states but every superposition is possible aswell. e.g. u can have 1/2 [11] + 1/2 [00]
however if you measure you will get 11 with 50% chance and 00 with 50%. This means as long as the quantum computer is computing u have all the superposition but as soon as you read the result (measure) the qbit are the same as normals bits and you have 4 possible states again.

The actual read/write process is more complex and most likely less efficient than it is with a classical bit.
